content.text: Post-traumatic endophthalmitis is a severe intraocular infection following an open globe injury (a full-thickness wound of the eye wall). The risk of developing endophthalmitis after such an injury ranges from 2% to 17% and is influenced by several factors. It is one of the most devastating complications of ocular trauma, often leading to severe vision loss or loss of the eye itself.

items: Delay in primary wound closure (>24 hours)
Presence of a retained intraocular foreign body (IOFB), especially if organic (e.g., wood, vegetable matter)
Dirty wound (e.g., injury in a rural setting)
Initial visual acuity of light perception or worse

content.text: The microbiology of post-traumatic endophthalmitis is diverse and often involves more virulent organisms than post-surgical cases.

pairs.value: Bacillus species (especially B. cereus) are notoriously virulent and common after soil-contaminated injuries. Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative staphylococci are also frequent. Streptococcus species and gram-negative organisms are also seen.
Fungal infections are more common than in post-surgical settings, particularly with injuries involving organic matter. Aspergillus and Fusarium are common culprits.

content.text: The onset is often rapid and fulminant, especially with organisms like Bacillus cereus, which can cause loss of the eye within 24-48 hours. Symptoms and signs are similar to other forms of acute endophthalmitis: severe pain, vision loss, hypopyon, and intense vitritis. The view of the posterior segment is often obscured by media opacity from the initial trauma and subsequent infection.
Management is an emergency and requires a combined medical and surgical approach.

items: Primary closure of the open globe injury as soon as possible.
Removal of any accessible intraocular foreign body.

procedureData.name: Vitreous Tap and Intravitreal Antibiotic Injection
procedureData.indication: Performed at the time of primary globe repair if endophthalmitis is suspected, or later if it develops.
procedureData.description: A vitreous sample is taken for culture. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are then injected.
procedureData.notes: Standard regimen is Vancomycin (1 mg/0.1 mL) and Ceftazidime (2.25 mg/0.1 mL). Amikacin may be considered for better Bacillus coverage, but it carries a risk of retinal toxicity. Clindamycin also has activity against Bacillus.

content.text: Systemic antibiotics are generally recommended in post-traumatic endophthalmitis, unlike in post-cataract surgery cases. A broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotic with good ocular penetration (e.g., a fourth-generation fluoroquinolone or ceftazidime) is often used.

procedureData.name: Pars Plana Vitrectomy (PPV)
procedureData.indication: Early vitrectomy is more strongly considered in post-traumatic cases than in post-surgical cases due to the high virulence of the infecting organisms and the presence of traumatic debris. It is often performed within 48 hours of diagnosis.
procedureData.description: PPV removes the infectious and inflammatory load and allows for better diffusion of antibiotics.

content.text: The role of prophylactic intravitreal antibiotics at the time of initial globe repair is controversial, but it is often performed in high-risk injuries. Systemic antibiotic prophylaxis is commonly given.
